citations.desc: Consignments to carriers and intermediate handlers.
citations.narrative:
On March 19, 2024, pet dog “Simba” arrived at Dulles International Airport (IAD) on EgyptAir flight MS981 as excess
baggage. No certification was attached to the transport enclosure documenting the last time food and water was offered
and there was no specific instructions for the next feeding and watering for a 24 hour period.
To ensure dogs are fed and watered during transport according to the standards and regulations of the AWA, the required
certifications for travel must be completed. A carrier must not accept a dog for travel without a certification signed by the
consignor that indicates the time and date the dog was fed and watered and instructions for the next feeding and watering
for a 24 hour period. The certification must be securely attached to the outside of the enclosure and easily readable.
Correct by May 20, 2024

citations.desc: Consignments to carriers and intermediate handlers.
citations.narrative:
On March 19, 2024, a pet dog “Simba” arrived at Dulles International Airport (IAD) on EgyptAir flight MS981 as excess
baggage. Cardboard was attached to the primary enclosure on the top and bottom. The cardboard extended extended on
the lower right side and the upper half of the left side. the left and right sides. The plastic extended around to the front
covering some of the surface area of the front of the crate. Absorbent pads were placed on the top and bottom of the
crate underneath the cardboard and inside the floor of the crate. The primary enclosure also did not have handholds. The
words “Live Animals” was not marked on the primary enclosure. There were no arrows to indicate the upright position.
In accordance with section 3.15(a)(5), the primary enclosure was not constructed in a manner to enable the enclosure to
be lifted without tilting or allowing a person to come in physical contact with the dog. The primary enclosure is also not
constructed as required in section 3.15(c) to ensure adequate ventilation during transit. The primary enclosure lacked the
proper labeling as outlined in section 3.15(a)(6) to ensure live dogs remain upright in the enclosure. Carriers must not
accept a dog for transport in commerce in a primary enclosure that does not meet all the requirements of section 3.15 of
Subpart A. Correct by May 20, 2024.
Egyptair promptly contacted EgyptAir headquarters and information about USDA regulations for transport, specifically
section 3.15, was sent out to all outstations.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
n

narrative:
3.14(c) 
   
Consignments to carriers and intermediate handlers. 
On March 19, 2024, pet dog “Simba” arrived at Dulles International Airport (IAD) on EgyptAir flight MS981 as excess 
baggage. No certification was attached to the transport enclosure documenting the last time food and water was offered 
and there was no specific instructions for the next feeding and watering for a 24 hour period. 
 
To ensure dogs are fed and watered during transport according to the standards and regulations of the AWA, the required 
certifications for travel must be completed. A carrier must not accept a dog for travel without a certification signed by the 
consignor that indicates the time and date the dog was fed and watered and instructions for the next feeding and watering 
for a 24 hour period. The certification must be securely attached to the outside of the enclosure and easily readable. 
Correct by May 20, 2024 
3.14(d) 
   
Consignments to carriers and intermediate handlers. 
On March 19, 2024, a pet dog “Simba” arrived at Dulles International Airport (IAD) on EgyptAir flight MS981 as excess 
baggage. Cardboard was attached to the primary enclosure on the top and bottom. The cardboard extended extended on 
the lower right side and the upper half of the left side. the left and right sides. The plastic extended around to the front 
covering some of the surface area of the front of the crate. Absorbent pads were placed on the top and bottom of the 
crate underneath the cardboard and inside the floor of the crate. The primary enclosure also did not have handholds. The 
words “Live Animals” was not marked on the primary enclosure. There were no arrows to indicate the upright position. 
 
In accordance with section 3.15(a)(5), the primary enclosure was not constructed in a manner to enable the enclosure to 
be lifted without tilting or allowing a person to come in physical contact with the dog. The primary enclosure is also not 
constructed as required in section 3.15(c) to ensure adequate ventilation during transit. The primary enclosure lacked the 
proper labeling as outlined in section 3.15(a)(6) to ensure live dogs remain upright in the enclosure. Carriers must not 
accept a dog for transport in commerce in a primary enclosure that does not meet all the requirements of section 3.15 of 
Subpart A. Correct by May 20, 2024. 
 
Egyptair promptly contacted EgyptAir headquarters and information about USDA regulations for transport, specifically 
section 3.15, was sent out to all outstations.

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
